headline: Paid Notice: Deaths GIARRAPUTO, LEONARD T.
summary: GIARRAPUTO--Leonard Thomas, on March 22, 2014, Leonard Thomas Giarraputo, of Reistertown, Maryland, Broadcasting Executive; beloved husband of Joy Civitella; devoted father of Barbara McLennan and Mark Giarraputo; loving grandfather of Ashley Horton, William McLennan, Jr., Cameron and Matthew Giarraputo. A memorial service will be held 10:30am, Wednesday, March 26, at St. Francis Xavier Church-Hunt Valley, MD. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions in Leonard's name may be made to HHT Foundation International Inc. (Osler-Weber-Rendu Syndrome) or Guiding Eyes For The Blind.

headline: Beware China Internet infatuation
summary: China Internet names like Alibaba and Sina Weibo are exploding onto the U.S. stage, but Breakingviews' Peter Thal Larsen warns enthusiasm shouldn't blind investors to the risks they carry.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths NOLAN, KATHLEEN
summary: NOLAN--Kathleen DeSales, on March 2, 2014, beloved wife of Barry Eigen; devoted mother of the late Christopher John Lenat; cherished daughter of John T. "Jack" and the late Margaret "Peggy" Nolan; dear sister of Margaret Ann Nolan, Mary Elizabeth Nolan-McGraw and Maureen Kazaras; also survived by eight nieces and nephews, two great nieces and one great-nephew. Family will receive friends on Thursday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Harry H. Witzke's Family Funeral Home, Inc., 4112 Old Columbia Pike, Ellicott City, MD. A Funeral Service will be held on Saturday at 11am at St. John's Episcopal Church. Interment Dulaney Valley Memorial Gardens. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to St. John's Episcopal Church for Pastoral Care, 9120 Frederick Rd., Ellicott City, MD 21042 or Our Daily Bread Employment Center, 725 The Fallsway, Baltimore, MD 21202 or online at www.catholiccharities-md.org/ our-daily-bread/

summary: NOLAN--Kathleen DeSales, on March 2, 2014, beloved wife of Barry Eigen; devoted mother of the late Christopher John Lenat; cherished daughter of John T. headline: Oracle misses
summary: Summary: Stocks rally as Russia’s Vladimir Putin says he won’t go beyond Crimea; Oracle struggles to catch up to the cloud; Microsoft hits July 2000 high on speculation Office is headed to the iPad.

headline: Sears Posts Loss for Quarter and Year in Tough Earnings Season for Many Retailers
summary: Sears lost $1.4 billion for the 2013 fiscal year and $358 million for the fourth quarter.

headline: Will Someone Please Make a Better Online Calendar?
summary: Magneto, an online scheduler, shows a lot of promise. It also shows a lot of rough edges.

headline: Apollo Chief Questions Effort to Limit Banks’ Exposure to Buyout Deals
summary: Leon D. Black, the head of Apollo Global Management, said on Friday that regulators instructing banks to avoid providing financing above a certain level of debt were “micromanaging.”

headline: Michelle Obama’s Bulkier Brows, Harry Brant’s Runway Moment and Dries Van Noten’s Curator Cameo
summary: Plus, why Coach is more popular than Gucci in China, who sat in H&M’s front row and more, as we run the numbers from the last week in style and culture.

headline: A Scorecard on Jos. A. Bank’s Latest Moves
summary: Jos. A. Bank’s rejection of the new bid from Men’s Wearhouse was expected. But what was surprising was that Jos. A. Bank laid out parameters for future talks over a deal, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.

headline: A Purpose Beyond Profit
summary: Over the past 15 years, something palpable has begun to change at big companies, Tony Schwartz writes. They are awakening to a larger perspective and a bigger view of the role they play in the world.

headline: ‘Blackfish’ in the Cross Hairs Again, and Other Developments
summary: SeaWorld questions an investigator’s ethics. And the subject of a nominated documentary short has died.

headline: Business and the Minimum Wage
summary: Paying workers more can help companies lower turnover and improve productivity.

headline: A Call to Give Consumers Their Credit Scores Free
summary: The federal Consumer Financial Protection Bureau urged credit card companies to give customers free copies of their credit scores.

headline: At the RSA Security Conference, Things Get Testy and Then They Get Awkward
summary: A look at some of the highlights, lowlights and more awkward happenings that took place at the annual RSA security conference this week.

headline: Buffett Hints at More Heinz-Like Deals in Annual Letter
summary: The challenge for Warren E. Buffett is whether Berkshire Hathaway can continue to make large acquisitions that will help the company grow at a pace that will sustain his reputation as the nation’s shrewdest investor.

headline: Now May Be a Good Time to Bail Out of Frequent-Flier Programs
summary: The rules are tightening further, with Delta Air Lines moving this week to a system that awards miles based on how much a passenger pays for a ticket.

headline: Engineers Allege Hiring Collusion in Silicon Valley
summary: A class-action suit by Silicon Valley engineers against companies including Google, Apple and Intel has revealed details of an agreement among them not to cold-call one another’s employees.

headline: Some Tech Interns Make More Than U.S. Workers
summary: Some interns at tech companies can make more than the median household income in the United States, according to a recent report by the career website Glassdoor.

headline: Also on the Menu at Empire Diner: New Memories
summary: The sound of first dates, business trips and strangers shooting the breeze fill a landmark spot in Chelsea.

headline: The Monuments of Tech
summary: The workplaces of Facebook, Twitter and Google may look whimsical. But each design is calculated to mirror its company’s values and culture.

headline: A Window-Washing Service on Two Wheels
summary: A bicycle is the way to travel for Phil Prado, a window-washer with clients all over Lower Manhattan and Midtown.

headline: The Rolling Robot Will Connect You Now
summary: Telepresence machines may soon become inexpensive enough for more everyday use, as a conduit for virtual visits among family and friends.

headline: Giving Early Taste of G.O.P. Tactics, Texans Make a Stand Against Obama
summary: During this primary election cycle, Republican candidates in Texas have rallied around common villains — President Obama and the federal government.

headline: Buffett and Icahn: Birds of a Feather?
summary: The styles of the two investors could not be more different. But Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews notes that both men beat the market by betting on America, playing hardball and trading on personal brands.

headline: H&R Block Ads Suggest the Only Certainties Are Death, Taxes — and Hipsters
summary: An online-only campaign pokes fun at a “hipster tax crisis” as April 15 approaches.

headline: The Mystery of Chinese New Year, Solved
summary: A little more than a week into the New Year, our whole team returned to us — including one particular employee with a heartwarming story.

headline: Trusting the ‘Sharing Economy’ to Regulate Itself
summary: Rather than challenging new forms of peer-to-peer commerce, like Airbnb or Uber, government should foster the kind of self-regulation that prevails in many established industries and professions, an economist writes.

headline: Rare Mutation Kills Off Gene Responsible for Diabetes
summary: Pfizer and Amgen teamed to develop drugs to mimic the effect, though it may take a decade or more before it is available to the public.

headline: The Challenges of Hiring and Working With Developers
summary: A group of business owners compare notes on the best strategies for hiring technical talent.

headline: Tiny Digital Publisher to Put Newsweek Back in Print
summary: IBT Media, a small digital publishing company that bought Newsweek for a pittance last summer, is poised to place the magazine on newsstands again this Friday.

headline: Buffett’s ‘Three T’s’ Open Up on CNBC
summary: The Berkshire executives Ted Weschler, Todd Combs and Tracy Britt Cool gave a rare interview on Monday.

headline: On GrubHub and Seamless, Restaurants Pay for Placement
summary: Restaurants that pay bigger commissions end up higher in search results.

headline: Andreessen Defends His Behavior on eBay’s Board
summary: In a post on the blog of his venture capital firm, Andreessen Horowitz, the technology investor Marc Andreessen defended his conduct as an eBay director in the face of repeated criticism from Carl C. Icahn.

headline: Fictional Disaster, Made to Sound Real, Draws F.C.C. Fine
summary: An effort to grab viewers’ attention and send them to the movie theater may have worked a little too well for Comcast, Viacom and Disney.

headline: Top Russians Face Sanctions by U.S. for Crimea Crisis
summary: The Obama administration suspended military ties to Russia, including exercises, port visits and planning meetings, just a day after calling off trade talks.

headline: In Change, Tourre Won’t Be Teaching University of Chicago Course
summary: The former Goldman Sachs trader had been scheduled to teach an undergraduate course on economic analysis beginning March 31. But a University of Chicago spokesman said on Tuesday that he would no longer be an instructor.

headline: The Writer Behind @GSElevator Speaks Out
summary: Remaining anonymous as he posted on Twitter under the handle @GSElevator was simply a “device” that allowed him to paint a broader picture of life on Wall Street, John LeFevre said on Tuesday.

headline: Apple’s New CarPlay Is Almost a Step in the Right Direction
summary: CarPlay system brings voice control, an iOS-like interface, maps and messaging into certain cars.

headline: A New Form of Shareholder Activism Gains Momentum
summary: Court battles over appraisal rights can be risky and expensive, but they also have benefits for hedge funds with a lot of money, Steven Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.

headline: Apple’s Departing Finance Chief Is Goldman’s Newest Director
summary: With his newly announced role at Goldman Sachs, Peter Oppenheimer, who plans to retire as Apple’s finance chief in September, deepens the longstanding ties between the investment bank and the technology giant.

headline: A Genetic Entrepreneur Sets His Sights on Aging and Death
summary: J. Craig Venter says his new company, Human Longevity, will focus on figuring out how people can live longer and healthier lives and will be the world’s largest human DNA sequencing operation.

headline: Sol Campbell’s Surprising Charge of Racism
summary: Few expected the former England captain to charge in his new biography that racism had kept him from leading England more often.

headline: Apple’s CarPlay Captivates the Auto Industry
summary: CarPlay links an Apple 5, 5c or 5s iPhone with the car’s infotainment system, letting the car use Apple’s apps.

headline: With Move to Limit Gun Sales, Facebook Is Caught in Debate
summary: Under pressure from law enforcement and advocacy groups, Facebook took steps Wednesday to regulate gun sales on its site as well as on its photo-sharing app Instagram.

headline: Big Data Picks Up the Pace
summary: Announcements from SAP, GoodData, Splunk and Tableau Software show how fast things are moving in the business of analyzing large amounts of data for companies.

headline: LinkedIn Co-Founder Defends EBay Against Icahn
summary: In a post on LinkedIn, Reid Hoffman criticized Carl C. Icahn’s campaign against eBay, arguing that the assault is rooted in short-term thinking that runs counter to Silicon Valley’s focus on long-term growth.

headline: To Spur Traffic at News Sites, Just Travoltify
summary: John Travolta’s mispronunciation of a name at the Oscars led the website Slate to create a feature to do the same with anyone’s name — the kind of interactive game now driving Web traffic.

headline: Daily Report: To Ensure a Secure Future, Bitcoin Might Need Oversight
summary: Some backers of the digital currency are calling for human oversight to guard against more losses like the $470 million collapse of Mt. Gox.

headline: No Longer Clashing, Wearable Tech Embraces Fashion

summary: Alpha Natural Resources and 66 of its subsidiaries agreed to reduce pollution from coal mines in Kentucky, Pennsylvania, Tennessee, Virginia and West Virginia.

summary: AT&T is introducing a major effort that highlights how connected young Americans are to their devices.

headline: A New SAT Aims to Realign With Schoolwork

headline: Golfers’ Will to Win Gets a Boost From Pit Crews for Aching Bodies
summary: As technology has become more unforgiving and players’ schedules more unrelenting, a cottage industry of pit crews employed to work on golfers’ bodies has taken root.

summary: After its merger with U.S. Airways, American Airlines will no longer offer bereavement fares.

headline: Like the Common Core? Then You’ll Like the New SAT
summary: Both the Common Core standards and the changes to the SAT exam are based on good intentions. They’re also riddled with hidden motivations and paths to unintended consequences, and that makes them hard to see clearly.

headline: New Democratic Strategy Goes After Koch Brothers
summary: Democrats are embarking on a broad effort that aims to unmask Charles G. and David H. Koch, the billionaire brothers who are perhaps the best-known patrons of conservative Republican politics.

summary: Harley unveiled a new model based upon a 1977 favorite, the Low Rider, as well as a lightweight touring bike called the SuperLow 1200T.

headline: Safeway Customers May Be Big Winners With Cerberus

headline: Lisa Falzone of Revel Systems on the Thrill of Entrepreneurship
summary: The chief executive of the maker of point-of-sale payments systems says remaining composed in front of employees is an important key to leading them effectively.

headline: With New Antipoverty Initiative, Salesforce C.E.O. Puts Silicon Valley on Spot
summary: Many have heard of the backlash against the tech industry in San Francisco. Now one executive is trying to convince his peers that charity should come with profits.

summary: Two new dramas — “Resurrection,” on ABC, and “Believe,” on NBC — feature children with supernatural traits.

headline: Top Official Can’t Rule on Cable Merger
summary: The Justice Department official, William Baer, represented NBCUniversal during its takeover by Comcast and is therefore forbidden from considering the merger.

headline: Guy Hands Drops Lawsuit Against Citigroup in U.S.

headline: Gun Safety on Facebook
summary: The fact that the company acknowledged some responsibility to act against illegal firearm sales is encouraging.

headline: Western Businesses in Russia, Watchful and Wary
summary: American players including Pepsi and McDonald’s are active in Russia. But for many West European businesses, that market is even more crucial.

headline: After Debit Card Fraud, a Chicago Bank Feels Its Customers’ Frustration
summary: First American Bank in Chicago got publicity but little satisfaction after it identified a source of debit card theft and tried to stop it.

headline: On Instagram, a Bazaar Where You Least Expect It
summary: Though not designed as an e-commerce site, Instagram can offer shoppers the thrill of discovery.

headline: A Whistle That’s Lost in the Crowd
summary: A bank loan investigation may yield no reward for the underwriter who sounded the alarm.

headline: The Languages of Twitter Users
summary: Gnip, a provider of social media data, tracked the primary languages chosen by Twitter users.

headline: The Youngest Technorati
summary: Teenage designers of apps and games have many incentives — financial and otherwise — to forget about their schoolwork.

headline: The Architects’ Role
summary: A reader responds to “Monuments of Tech” (March 2).

headline: When Employees Confess, Sometimes Falsely

headline: In West Chelsea, a Temporary Emporium
summary: The sales office for a condo development is built from scratch and will be rented out after the building is sold out.

headline: Stop Glorifying Hackers

headline: Francisco Costa
summary: The Calvin Klein designer’s influences are tied to his house, his hometown and his own intuition.

headline: The ‘Boys’ in the Bunkhouse
summary: For decades, dozens of men with intellectual disabilities lived in an old schoolhouse and worked in a turkey plant. No one knew just what they endured.

headline: Jeff Lawson of Twilio: When Ideas Collide, Don’t Duck
summary: “Conflict shouldn’t be taboo,” says the chief executive of a cloud communications company. “In fact, resolving conflict is one of the key things companies do.”

headline: The Playground Set Gets Its Own Bras
summary: Bralettes — half camisoles with narrow straps — are catching on with young girls.

summary: An acquaintance in Beijing recently brought up the discrimination bill and asked me, “Why is Arizona was so un-American?”

headline: Boldly Upsetting the Field, and the Establishment

headline: First Look Media Adds Editor of Gawker
summary: The online news venture backed by the technology billionaire Pierre M. Omidyar is adding John Cook, the editor of Gawker, to its growing stable of established journalists.

headline: Patentholder on Breast Cancer Tests Denied Injunction in Lawsuit

headline: Sprint Owner’s New Appeal for Merger With T-Mobile
summary: Masayoshi Son, the founder of SoftBank, took an unusual tack in a rare address to an American audience on Tuesday, saying that he wants to rescue the United States from broadband oblivion.

summary: Masayoshi Son, the founder of SoftBank, took an unusual tack in a rare address to an American audience on Tuesday, saying that he wants to rescue the United States from broadband oblivion.

headline: Report Says Medication Use Is Rising for Adults With Attention Disorder
summary: Some experts said the report indicated that the disorder is being diagnosed and treated with medication in children far too often, and that steeply rising diagnoses among adults might portend similar problems.

headline: Extended-Stay Hotels Climb in Manhattan
summary: Corporate or short-term housing units have proliferated across Manhattan, both in buildings dedicated solely to this function or scattered inside existing rentals and condos.

headline: Candy Crush Maker Picks Valuation From Thin Air
summary: As King Digital Entertainment, the maker of the popular game Candy Crush Saga, prepares to go public, it is difficult to calculate what it’s worth when its profit can skyrocket 70-fold one year and could collapse the next, writes Robert Cyran in Reuters Breakingviews.

headline: Universities Try a Cultural Bridge to Lure Foreign Students
summary: Oregon State University is among a growing number of academic institutions that are teaming up with private companies to lure foreign students with yearlong transitional programs.

summary: The hedge fund Elliott Management is raising its bet on Juniper Networks after the networking equipment company announced a series of new initiatives.

headline: For S.E.C., a Much-Needed Win

summary: Getting a ticket to see the show would have required the kind of social-media shillling that I don’t think anyone’s friends or followers should be subjected to.

headline: Mobile Security Specialist Lookout to Announce New Chief Executive
summary: Lookout, the mobile security app creator, is bringing on Jim Dolce as its new chief executive, as it grows from consumer start-up to full-fledged security firm.

summary: The food blog will start reviewing as part of an ambitious expansion under its new owner, Vox Media.

headline: The Unhealthy Meat Market

headline: Charter Still Hanging Around Time Warner Cable
summary: Charter has yet to withdraw the full slate of directors that it nominated to Time Warner Cable’s board just one day before Comcast swooped in.

headline: A Theory Behind Surge in Xbox One Sales
summary: In sales figures for February released Thursday afternoon by NPD, the retail tracking firm, Microsoft’s Xbox One nearly matched the U.S. sales of the PlayStation 4. That was a sharp narrowing of the lead Sony had in monthly sales, leading to speculation that Sony fans are getting tired of hunting for the PlayStation 4, which is in short supply.

headline: Dan Harris, Co-Anchor of ‘Nightline,’ Discusses Multitasking and Meditation
summary: Dan Harris, a co-anchor of Nightline, has just published a new book that says meditation can make us 10 percent happier and that multitasking in a technology-obsessed world is detrimental to our brains.

summary: Plus, picking a drive for Apple’s Time Machine.

headline: The Best 401(k)s Set a Higher Bar for Others

summary: A car-themed hotel in Germany offers beds made out of classic cars; N.T.S.B. head steps down to lead safety advocacy non-profit.

headline: Standing for More Than a Century, Only to Vanish in an Instant
summary: The two buildings that were wiped out by an explosion had been fixtures on their block in East Harlem since 1910.

summary: The desktop search advertising business, long the most reliably profitable on the web, will decrease $1.4 billion this year, according to eMarketer, while mobile search revenue will nearly double.

summary: A review of five cameras that are in the same price range but offer different features.

headline: This Is the Real Reason Sbarro Is in Bankruptcy

summary: Warren E. Buffett prefers to use Berkshire Hathaway’s huge cash pile to buy up companies, rather than return it to shareholders.

headline: Uber Expands Insurance Program for Community Drivers

Now the company says it is buying more insurance for its drivers.

headline: Spring Cleaning Who Has Access to Your Data
summary: As spring comes into view, it’s time to manage which apps and services have access to your social accounts and can see everything you’re doing.

summary: The chief executive of Clarizen, a work management software company, says leadership is about asking the right questions.

summary: The annual fee for Amazon Prime, the two-day shipping service, will jump 25 percent, to $99.

headline: Pharrell’s Phragrance, Karl’s Custom Emojis and Obama’s Shopping Trip
summary: Plus, Vogue Italia’s controversy-baiting editorial, Tehran goes mad for models and more from the week in style.

headline: Wendy’s Turns Up Volume on Adoption Drive
summary: Wendy’s has long supported adoption, but now the company is putting it front and center with a national advertising campaign and an adoption hub on its website.

summary: A Lexington man has been charged with threatening to kill Gov. Steven L. Beshear, his wife and their family in a series of Facebook postings.

summary: A US Airways plane’s nose gear collapsed Thursday as its pilot attempted an emergency landing, forcing an evacuation of the plane but no serious injuries, officials said.

headline: Preserving Family History, One Memory at a Time
summary: StoryWorth is among new services that are helping relatives build an online treasure chest of anecdotes.

summary: In start-up land, the young barely talk to the old (and vice versa). That makes for a lot of cool apps. But great technology? Not so much.

headline: Mathematicians Are Hoping Their Calculations Add Up to the Perfect Bracket
summary: The reason behind their motivation? How about 1 billion of them? That is the number of dollars offered by Quicken Loans for an unblemished result in predicting N.C.A.A. tournament games

headline: To Change Tunes, a Nod Will Be as Good as a Wink
summary: Automakers, including Mercedes-Benz and Ford, are cautiously installing gesture sensing systems that read hand and head motions as computer commands.

summary: Readers ask questions about a gang leader caught carrying a book of poems as well as the reason for green lights outside police precinct stations.

summary: We’ve replaced contained chaos with something so vast that we need algorithms to show us our way.

headline: Shawn Jenkins of Benefitfocus: A C.E.O. Is Like a Flight Instructor
summary: The chief executive of a benefits technology company says good leaders let employees learn by experience. “I’ve got to be willing to let you fail a pretty good amount, almost to the point of danger,” he says.

summary: New websites can help investors and others gather wide-ranging government data about a particular business.

headline: Lithium Producer Chases Tesla’s Bold Battery Plan

summary: Ann Cairns, president of MasterCard’s global operations outside North America, on ways to give feedback.

summary: Steve Jurvetson, a venture capitalist who has invested in space start-ups, discusses the future of space, amateur rockets and people living on Mars.

summary: New Jersey is the latest state to bar Tesla’s stores for its electric vehicles under laws that favor independent dealerships.

summary: The new Aerin Essentials Collection includes Rose Balm, a super-hydrating product that also serves as the base for a new set of 10 lipsticks.

summary: The retailing giant is expected to announce that on March 26 it will begin allowing customers to convert their old games into credits in over 3,100 Walmart stores nationwide.

headline: Google Unveils Software for Smartwatches-to-Be
summary: In a pre-emptive move against Apple, Google revealed Android Wear, a version of the Android operating system that is tailored for wearable computers.

headline: Plenty of Ways to Try for a Billion-Dollar Prize
summary: A lighthearted look at three distinct approaches to picking the 67 games in the N.C.A.A. men’s basketball tournament in hopes of winning a $1 billion reward from Warren Buffett.

headline: Apple to Offer Cheaper iPhone 5C in Several Markets
summary: The colorful plastic iPhone hasn’t been as big a hit as the high-end iPhone 5S. So to lure more customers, Apple is introducing another model in a few markets, including China.

headline: Reading, Writing and Renewal (the Urban Kind)
summary: A new public school that also includes a community center and other public amenities is part of a joint project designed to revitalize a blighted section of East Baltimore.

headline: A Conversation With Yukari Kane, Author of ‘Haunted Empire: Apple After Steve Jobs’
summary: In an interview, Ms. Kane talked about the highlights of her new book, and a company struggling to cope with the loss of its visionary founder.

headline: How to Profit Modestly by Moving to a Nonprofit
summary: Colleges across the country offer programs intended to prepare unemployed corporate professionals, or those looking to make career transitions, for the expanding nonprofit sector.

headline: Can You Trust ‘Secure’ Messaging Apps?
summary: Messaging apps and security are two of the hottest topics in tech. But can you trust the wave of supposedly secure messaging services coming out now? The New York Times’s Molly Wood talks to an expert.

headline: Former Goldman Chief Walks Among Warriors and Dragons
summary: Stephen Friedman, the onetime head of Goldman Sachs, appears in humble garb during a cameo appearance in the upcoming season of the HBO series “Game of Thrones.”

headline: New Social App Has Juicy Posts, All Anonymous
summary: Posts on Secret, an app that allows users to upload anonymous messages, can range from benign to inappropriate and are testing the tech industry’s appetite for sharing.

headline: Free-for-All on the Final Friday of Tribeca Film Festival
summary: As the presenting sponsor of the festival for the first time, the company is introducing an effort, “Film for All,” that aims to expose the festival to more New Yorkers.

headline: Icahn Calls on eBay to Sell 20% of PayPal Unit to the Public
summary: The activist investor’s proposal, a retreat from his previous demand that the payment processor be spun out completely from its parent, still calls for a separation of the two businesses.

headline: Judge Sides with F.T.C. in Payday Lending Case
summary: A federal judge has reinforced the Federal Trade Commission’s authority to go after payday lenders that claim their ties to Native American tribes make them immune to laws restricting high-cost loans.

headline: Your Questions, My Answers (III)
summary: A columnist faces his readers, yet again.

headline: Odd Birds
summary: Willy Puchner’s “ABC of Fabulous Princesses” imagines princesses as exotic birds, and Kate Samworth’s “Aviary Wonders Inc.” takes the form of a manual for building your own birds.

headline: Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin to Star in a Netflix Comedy Series
summary: “Grace and Frankie,” coming to Netflix next year, will feature Jane Fonda and Lily Tomlin as rivals who find their husbands are in love with each other.

headline: Questions Over Goldman Deal as Investors Sit in the Dark
summary: In a fight over a hotel company that went “dark,” investors have accused Goldman Sachs of having conflicting interests, writes Jesse Eisinger in The Trade column.

headline: Cheese Curds, a Riff on Cronuts, a Paris Ham and More
summary: Recommendations for the week of March 18.

headline: The Billion Dollar Bracket Challenge Is Really a Hundred Thousand Dollar Lottery
summary: The mathematical odds of winning the Grand Prize are 1:9,223,372,036,854,775,808.

headline: After Derivatives, a Bet on Crispy Seaweed
summary: Robert Mock, who once sold financial derivatives at Bank of America Merrill Lynch, has found new success making seaweed chips. The venture has attracted backers including Jerry Yang, a co-founder of Yahoo.

headline: In Defense of Anonymous Political Giving
summary: The Koch brothers’ historical case for secret donations.

headline: Apple After Jobs: Pretty Much the Same as Ever
summary: A new book on Apple’s state after Steve Jobs paints a dire picture of a company losing its way. Farhad Manjoo disagrees.

headline: An Unrewarded Leap of Faith
summary: Shopping at Flight 23 in Midtown Manhattan, where the best Jordans are on the customers.

headline: Facebook’s Hack, a Language of Tech Competition
summary: The world’s biggest social network introduced on Thursday a new open-source software language that is focused on helping to build interactive web pages. Besides winning geek credibility, it’s the latest version of a decades-old effort in tech to win over as many developers as possible.

headline: Shopping Openings and Events for the Week of March 19
summary: A Topshop x Adidas capsule collection in store now; the Nike + R.T. Air Force 1 collection lands at Dover Street Market on Friday and more.

headline: Turning a Tablet Into a Child’s Interactive TV
summary: The Winston Show, which is an iPad-only program, is an example of the new content types that are possible when a TV is also a hand-held computer.

headline: Golden Gate Buys Stake in Parent of Ann Taylor
summary: Golden Gate, the private equity firm, disclosed in a regulatory filing on Thursday that it had purchased a roughly 9.5 percent stake in Ann Inc., with the aim of bolstering the retailer’s stock price.

headline: Breaking From Donor Dependence
summary: Institutions grapple with expanding their profit-making activities as government and private financing dwindles.

headline: $80 Million for 6 Weeks for Cable Chief
summary: Robert D. Marcus will receive a severance payment that amounts to more than $1 million a day for the six weeks he ran Time Warner Cable before agreeing to sell.

headline: What Does $1.8 Billion Get You in Men’s Wear?

headline: Why Android Wear Is the Beginning of the Wearable Devices Era
summary: Every hardware platform needs software to be successful. By giving manufacturers a known operating system to work with, Google’s Android Wear will jump-start the wearables industry, says Molly Wood.

headline: Art Book Depicting Murder Inc. Is No Steal
summary: The collector’s edition of “The Brownsville Boys: Jewish Gangsters of Murder, Inc.” is lavishly illustrated, printed and boxed, and sells for $4,200 per copy.

summary: After being a fixture in Midtown Manhattan for more than seven decades, the magazine publisher is considering relocating to an area that has become a lower-cost alternative for corporations.

summary: The chief of a big-data company says using processes that can’t be quantified often means you aren’t asking the right questions.

headline: U.S. and California Officials Enter Battle Over Facebook Privacy Settlement

headline: Sit Back and Soak Awhile in Natural Springs
summary: An ancient practice is revived by travelers interested in natural treatments.

summary: Questions about a hepatitis C drug affects biotech companies.

headline: Third-Party Hotel Booking Sites Can Mislead Consumers

A new report shows how much work it is, getting us to this level of frustration.

summary: The City of Memphis tapped the municipal bond market to finance the $19 million purchase of AutoZone Park, the home of the Memphis Redbirds, a farm team that the St. Louis Cardinals will buy for $15 million.

summary: Two recent research papers, examining Google Flu Trends, offer a critique of big-data analysis.

summary: Owners of Apple’s tablet will be able to use Word, Excel, PowerPoint and other popular productivity tools — but they still may not want to.

headline: Seeking a Town on the Border of Fiction and Reality
summary: Google recently removed Agloe, N.Y., in the western Catskills, from its map, but how it endured on area charts for so long remains a cartographic mystery.

summary: A group of 12 women said they were paid less than men and were sexually harassed while working for the company’s stores, Jared and Kay Jewelers.

summary: If its acquisition of Time Warner Cable is approved, Comcast will become much more than a regional cable company, says its chief executive, Brian Roberts.

summary: Representative Mike Rogers of Michigan made the announcement just days after proposing an ambitious overhaul of electronic surveillance programs.

summary: The chief executive of an open-source software company says he wants to hire people “who are going to jump in and own their work, who are going to risk something, and risk failing.”

summary: Michael Lewis, whose new book, “Flash Boys,” goes on sale on Monday, is revisiting the ills of capitalism.

summary: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: A steamer cut in two after a collision at sea in 1889, and an associate of the heavyweight boxer Sonny Liston denies fronting for criminals in 1964.

headline: A Lone Ranger of the 401(k)’s
summary: A lawyer’s string of cases highlights a corporate responsibility to monitor the costs and fees in employees’ retirement plans.

summary: Judge Lucy H. Koh, who gained fame during her handling of the high-profile patent infringement lawsuit between Apple and Samsung Electronics, has become the de facto judge for landmark Silicon Valley lawsuits.

summary: In Hollywood’s sea of bravado, Kevin Tsujihara, the quiet new chief executive of Warner Bros., may seem miscast. But he is already making bold bets to keep the studio on top.

summary: The social network has made some recent moves that suggest it is determined to follow its own path, regardless of what outsiders think.

summary: The Asia-Pacific Association for International Education holds a conference in Seoul, covering topics as varied as rankings and online learning.

headline: Hollywood’s Antipiracy Efforts Add New Voice
summary: Ruth Vitale, an independent film executive, was recently named executive director of CreativeFuture, a new force in the copyright wars.
